speech.line: Why then to morrow night, on Tueſday morne,
On Tueſday noone, or night; on Wenſday Morne.
I prythee name the time, but let it not
Exceed three dayes. Infaith hee’s penitent:
And yet his Treſpaſſe, in our common reaſon
(Saue that they ſay the warres muſt make example)
Out of her beſt, is not almoſt a fault
T’ encurre a priuate checke. When ſhall he come?
Tell me Othello. I wonder in my Soule
What you would aske me, that I ſhould deny,
Or ſtand ſo mam’ring on? What? Michael Caſſio,
That came a woing with you? and ſo many a time
(When I haue ſpoke of you diſpraiſingly)
Hath tane your part, to haue ſo much to do
To bring him in? Truſt me, I could do much.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Prythee no more: Let him come when he will:
I will deny thee nothing.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Why, this is not a Boone:
‘Tis as I ſhould entreate you weare your Gloues,
Or feede on nouriſhing diſhes, or keepe you warme,
Or ſue to you, to do a peculiar profit
To your owne perſon. Nay, when I haue a ſuite
Wherein I meane to touch your Loue indeed,
It ſhall be full of poize, and difficult waight,
And fearefull to be granted.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I will deny thee nothing.
Whereon, I do beſeech thee, grant me this,
To leaue me but a little to my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Shall I deny you? No: farewell my Lord.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Farewell my Deſdemona, Ile come to thee ſtrait.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Æmilia come; be as your Fancies teach you:
What ere you be, I am obedient.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Excellent wretch: Perdition catch my Soule
But I do loue thee: and when I loue thee not,
Chaos is come againe.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: My Noble Lord.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: What doſt thou ſay, Iago?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Did Michael Caſſio
When he woo’d my Lady, know of your loue?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: He did, from firſt to laſt:
Why doſt thou aske?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: But for a ſatisfaƈtion of my Thought,
No further harme.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Why of thy thought, Iago?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I did not thinke he had bin acquainted with hir.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: O yes, and went betweene vs very oft.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Indeed?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Indeed? I indeed. Diſcern’ſt thou ought in that?
Is he not honeſt?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Honeſt, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Honeſt? I, Honeſt.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: My Lord, for ought I know.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: What do’ſt thou thinke?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Thinke, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Thinke, my Lord? Alas, thou ecchos’t me;
As if there were ſome Monſter in thy thought
Too hideous to be ſhewne. Thou doſt mean ſomthing:
I heard thee ſay euen now, thou lik’ſt not that,
When Caſsio left my wife. What didd’ſt not like?
And when I told thee, he was of my Counſaile,
Of my whole courſe of wooing; thou cried’ſt, Indeede?
And didd’ſt contraƈt, and purſe thy brow together,
As if thou then hadd’ſt ſhut vp in thy Braine
Some horrible Conceite. If thou do’ſt loue me,
Shew me thy thought.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: My Lord, you know I loue you.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I thinke thou do’ſt:
And for I know thou’rt full of Loue, and Honeſtie,
And weigh’ſt thy words before thou giu’ſt them breath,
Therefore theſe ſtops of thine, fright me the more:
For ſuch things in a falſe diſloyall Knaue
Are trickes of Cuſtome: but in a man that’s iuſt,
They’re cloſe dilations, working from the heart,
That Paſſion cannot rule.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: For Michael Caſsio,
I dare be ſworne, I thinke that he is honeſt.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I thinke ſo too.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Men ſhould be what they ſeeme,
Or thoſe that be not, would they might ſeeme none.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Certaine, men ſhould be what they ſeeme.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Why then I thinke Caſsio’s an honeſt man.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Nay, yet there’s more in this?
I prythee ſpeake to me, as to thy thinkings,
As thou doſt ruminate, and giue thy worſt of thoughts
The worſt of words.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Good my Lord pardon me,
Though I am bound to euery Aƈte of dutie,
I am not bound to that: All Slaues are free:
Vtter my Thoughts? Why ſay, they are vild, and falce?
As where’s that Palace, whereinto foule things
Sometimes intrude not? Who ha’s that breaſt ſo pure,
Wherein vncleanly Apprehenſions
Keepe Leetes, and Law-dayes, and in Seſſions ſit
With meditations lawfull?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Thou do’ſt conſpire againſt thy Friend (Iago)
If thou but think’ſt him wrong’d, and mak’ſt his eare
A ſtranger to thy Thoughts.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I do beſeech you,
Though I perchance am vicious in my gueſſe
(As I confeſſe it is my Natures plague
To ſpy into Abuſes, and of my iealouſie
Shapes faults that are not) that your wiſedome
From one, that ſo imperfeƈtly conceits,
Would take no notice, nor build your ſelfe a trouble
Out of his ſcattering, and vnſure obſeruance:
It were not for your quiet, nor your good,
Nor for my Manhood, Honeſty, and Wiſedome,
To let you know my thoughts.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: What doſt thou meane?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Good name in Man, & woman (deere my Lord)
Is the immediate Iewell of their Soules;
Who ſteales my purſe, ſteales traſh:
‘Tis ſomething, nothing;
‘Twas mine, ‘tis his, and has bin ſlaue to thouſands:
But he that filches from me my good Name,
Robs me of that, which not enriches him,
And makes me poore indeed.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Ile know thy Thoughts.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: You cannot, if my heart were in your hand,
Nor ſhall not, whil’ſt ‘tis in my cuſtodie.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Ha?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Oh, beware my Lord, of iealouſie,
It is the greene-ey’d Monſter, which doth mocke
The meate it feeds on. That Cuckold liues in bliſſe,
Who certaine of his Fate, loues not his wronger:
But oh, what damned minutes tels he ore,
Who dotes, yet doubts: Suſpeƈts, yet ſoundly loues?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: O miſerie.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Poore, and Content, is rich, and rich enough,
But Riches fineleſſe, is as poore as Winter,
To him that euer feares he ſhall be poore:
Good Heauen, the Soules of all my Tribe defend
From Iealouſie.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Why? why is this?
Think’ſt thou, I’ld make a Life of Iealouſie;
To follow ſtill the changes of the Moone
With freſh ſuſpitionſ? No: to be once in doubt,
Is to be reſolu’d: Exchange me for a Goat,
When I ſhall turne the buſineſſe of my Soule
To ſuch exufflicate, and blow’d Surmiſes,
Matching thy inference. ‘Tis not to make me Iealious,
To ſay my wife is faire, feeds well, loues company,
Is free of Speech, Sings, Playes, and Dances:
Where Vertue is, theſe are more vertuous.
Nor from mine owne weake merites, will I draw
The ſmalleſt feare, or doubt of her reuolt,
For ſhe had eyes, and choſe me. No Iago,
Ile ſee before I doubt; when I doubt, proue;
And on the proofe, there is no more but this,
Away at once with Loue, or Iealouſie.

speech.speaker: Ia.
speech.line: I am glad of this: For now I ſhall haue reaſon
To ſhew the Loue and Duty that I beare you
With franker ſpirit. Therefore (as I am bound)
Receiue it from me. I ſpeake not yet of proofe:
Looke to your wife, obſerue her well with Caſſio,
Weare your eyes, thus: not Iealious, nor Secure:
I would not haue your free, and Noble Nature,
Out of ſelfe-Bounty, be abus’d: Looke too’t:
I know our Country diſpoſition well:
In Venice, they do let Heauen ſee the prankes
They dare not ſhew their Husbands.
Their beſt Conſcience,
Is not to leaue’t vndone, but kept vnknowne.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Doſt thou ſay ſo?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: She did deceiue her Father, marrying you,
And when ſhe ſeem’d to ſhake, and feare your lookes,
She lou’d them moſt.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: And ſo ſhe did.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Why go too then:
Shee that ſo young could giue out ſuch a Seeming
To ſeele her Fathers eyes vp, cloſe as Oake,
He thought ’twas Witchcraft.
But I am much too blame:
I humbly do beſeech you of your pardon
For too much louing you.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I am bound to thee for euer.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I ſee this hath a little daſh’d your Spirits:

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Not a iot, not a iot.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Truſt me, I feare it has:
I hope you will conſider what is ſpoke
Comes from your Loue.
But I do ſee y’are moou’d:
I am to pray you, not to ſtraine my ſpeech
To groſſer iſſues, nor to larger reach,
Then to Suſpition.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I will not.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Should you do ſo (my Lord)
My ſpeech ſhould fall into ſuch vilde ſucceſſe,
Which my Thoughts aym’d not.
Caſſio’s my worthy Friend:
My Lord, I ſee y’are mou’d.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: No, not much mou’d:
I do not thinke but Deſdemona’s honeſt.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Long liue ſhe ſo;
And long liue you to thinke ſo.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: And yet how Nature erring from it ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I, there’s the point:
As (to be bold with you)
Not to affeƈt many propoſed Matches
Of her owne Clime, Complexion, and Degree,
Whereto we ſee in all things, Nature tends:
Foh, one may ſmel in ſuch, a will moſt ranke,
Foule diſproportions, Thoughts vnnaturall.
But (pardon me) I do not in poſition
Diſtinƈtly ſpeake of her, though I may feare
Her will, recoyling to her better iudgement,
May fal to match you with her Country formes,
And happily repent.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Farewell, farewell:
If more thou doſt perceiue, let me know more:
Set on thy wife to obſerue.
Leaue me Iago.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: My Lord, I take my leaue.

speech.speaker: Othel.
speech.line: Why did I marry?
This honeſt Creature (doubtleſſe)
Sees, and knowes more, much more then he vnfolds.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: My Lord, I would I might intreat your Honor
To ſcan this thing no farther: Leaue it to time,
Although ‘tis fit that Caſſio haue his Place;
For ſure he filles it vp with great Ability;
Yet if you pleaſe, to him off a-while:
You ſhall by that perceiue him, and his meanes:
Note if your Lady ſtraine his Entertainment
With any ſtrong, or vehement importunitie,
Much will be ſeene in that: In the meane time,
Let me be thought too buſie in my feares,
(As worthy cauſe I haue to feare I am)
And hold her free, I do beſeech your Honor.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Feare not my gouernment.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I once more take my leaue.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: This Fellow’s of exceeding honeſty,
And knowes all Quantities with a learn’d Spirit
Of humane dealings. If I do proue her Haggard,
Though that her Ieſſes were my deere heart-ſtrings,
I’ld whiſtle her off, and let her downe the winde
To prey at Fortune. Haply, for I am blacke,
And haue not thoſe ſoft parts of Conuerſation
That Chamberers haue: Or for I am declin’d
Into the vale of yeares (yet that’s not much)
Shee’s gone. I am abus’d, and my releefe
Muſt be to loath her. Oh Curſe of Marriage!
That we can call theſe delicate Creatures ours,
And not their Appetites? I had rather be a Toad,
And liue vpon the vapour of a Dungeon,
Then keepe a corner in the thing I loue
For others vſes. Yet ‘tis the plague to Great-ones,
Prerogatiu’d are they leſſe then the Baſe,
‘Tis deſtiny vnſhunnable, like death:
Euen then, this forked plague is Fated to vs,
When we do quicken. Looke where ſhe comes:
If ſhe be falſe, Heauen mock’d it ſelfe:
Ile not beleeue’t.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: How now, my deere Othello?
Your dinner, and the generous Iſlanders
By you inuited, do attend your preſence.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I am too blame.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Why do you ſpeake ſo faintly?
Are you not well?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I haue a paine vpon my Forehead, heere.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Why that’s with watching, ‘twill away againe.
Let me but binde it hard, within this houre
It will be well.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Your Napkin is too little:
Let it alone: Come, Ile go in with you.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I am very ſorry that you are not well.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: I am glad I haue found this Napkin:
This was her firſt remembrance from the Moore,
My wayward Husband hath a hundred times
Woo’d me to ſteale it. But ſhe ſo loues the Token,
(For he coniur’d her, ſhe ſhould euer keepe it)
That ſhe reſerues it euermore about her,
To kiſſe, and talke too. Ile haue the worke tane out,
And giu’t Iago: what he will do with it
Heauen knowes, not I:
I nothing, but to pleaſe his Fantaſie.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: How now? What do you heere alone?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Do not you chide: I haue a thing for you.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: You haue a thing for me?
It is a common thing—

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Hah?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: To haue a fooliſh wife.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Oh, is that all? What will you giue me now
For that ſame Handkerchiefe.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: What Handkerchiefe?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: What Handkerchiefe?
Why that the Moore firſt gaue to Deſdemona,
That which ſo often you did bid me ſteale.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Haſt ſtolne it from her?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: No: but ſhe let it drop by negligence,
And to th’ aduantage, I being heere, took’t vp:
Looke, heere ‘tis.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: A good wench, giue it me.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: What will you do with’t, that you haue bene
ſo earneſt to haue me filch it?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Why, what is that to you?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: If it be not for ſome purpoſe of import,
Giu’t me againe. Poore Lady, ſhee’l run mad
When ſhe ſhall lacke it.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Be not acknowne on’t:
I haue vſe for it. Go, leaue me.
I will in Caſſio’s Lodging looſe this Napkin,
And let him finde it. Trifles light as ayre,
Are to the iealious, confirmations ſtrong,
As proofes of holy Writ. This may do ſomething.
The Moore already changes with my poyſon:
Dangerous conceites, are in their Natures poyſons,
Which at the firſt are ſcarſe found to diſtaſte:
But with a little aƈte vpon the blood,
Burne like the Mines of Sulphure. I did ſay ſo.
Looke where he comes: Not Poppy, nor Mandragora,
Nor all the drowſie Syrrups of the world
Shall euer medicine thee to that ſweete ſleepe
Which thou owd’ſt yeſterday.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Ha, ha, falſe to mee?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Why how now Generall? No more of that.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Auant, be gone: Thou haſt ſet me on the Racke:
I ſweare ‘tis better to be much abus’d,
Then but to know’t a little.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: How now, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: What ſenſe had I, in her ſtolne houres of Luſt?
I ſaw’t not, thought it not: it harm’d not me:
I ſlept the next night well, fed well, was free, and merrie.
I found not Caſſio’s kiſſes on her Lippes:
He that is robb’d, not wanting what is ſtolne,
Let him not know’t, and he’s not robb’d at all.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I am ſorry to heare this?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I had beene happy, if the generall Campe,
Pyoners and all, had taſted her ſweet Body,
So I had nothing knowne. Oh now, for euer
Farewell the Tranquill minde; farewell Content;
Farewell the plumed Troopes, and the bigge Warres,
That makes Ambition, Vertue! Oh farewell,
Farewell the neighing Steed, and the ſhrill Trumpe,
The Spirit-ſtirring Drum, th’ Eare-piercing Fife,
The Royall Banner, and all Qualitie,
Pride, Pompe, and Circumſtance of glorious Warre:
And O you mortall Engines, whoſe rude throates
Th’ immortall Ioues dread Clamours, counterfet,
Farewell: Othello’s Occupation’s gone.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Is’t poſſible my Lord?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Villaine, be ſure thou proue my Loue a Whore;
Be ſure of it: Giue me the Occular proofe,
Or by the worth of mine eternall Soule,
Thou had’ſt bin better haue bin borne a Dog
Then anſwer my wak’d wrath.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Is’t come to this?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Make me to ſee’t: or (at the leaſt) ſo proue it,
That the probation beare no Hindge, nor Loope,
To hang a doubt on: Or woe vpon thy life.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: My Noble Lord.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: If thou doſt ſlander her, and torture me,
Neuer pray more: Abandon all remorſe
On Horrors head, Horrors accumulate:
Do deeds to make Heauen weepe, all Earth amaz’d;
For nothing canſt thou to damnation adde,
Greater then that.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: O Grace! O Heauen forgiue me!
Are you a Man? Haue you a Soule? or Senſe?
God buy you: take mine Office. Oh wretched Foole,
That lou’ſt to make thine Honeſty, a Vice!
Oh monſtrous world! Take note, take note (O World)
To be direƈt and honeſt, is not ſafe.
I thanke you for this profit, and from hence
Ile loue no Friend, ſith Loue breeds ſuch offence.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Nay ſtay: thou ſhould’ſt be honeſt.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I ſhould be wiſe; for Honeſtie’s a Foole,
And looſes that it workes for.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: By the World,
I thinke my Wife be honeſt, and thinke ſhe is not:
I thinke that thou art iuſt, and thinke thou art not:
Ile haue ſome proofe. My name that was as freſh
As Dians Viſage, is now begrim’d and blacke
As mine owne face. If there be Cords, or Kniues,
Poyſon, or Fire, or ſuffocating ſtreames,
Ile not indure it. Would I were ſatisfied.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I ſee you are eaten vp with Paſſion:
I do repent me, that I put it to you.
You would be ſatisfied?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Would? Nay, and I will.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: And may: but how? How ſatisfied, my Lord?
Would you the ſuper-viſion groſſely gape on?
Behold her top’d?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Death, and damnation. Oh!

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: It were a tedious difficulty, I thinke,
To bring them to that Proſpeƈt: Damne them then,
If euer mortall eyes do ſee them boulſter
More then their owne. What then? How then?
What ſhall I ſay? Where’s Satisfaƈtion?
It is impoſſible you ſhould ſee this,
Were they as prime as Goates, as hot as Monkeyes,
As ſalt as Wolues in pride, and Fooles as groſſe
As Ignorance, made drunke. But yet, I ſay,
If imputation, and ſtrong circumſtances,
Which leade direƈtly to the doore of Truth,
Will giue you ſatisfaƈtion, you might haue’t.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Giue me a liuing reaſon ſhe’s diſloyall.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I do not like the Office.
But ſith I am entred in this cauſe ſo farre
(Prick’d too’t by fooliſh Honeſty, and Loue)
I will go on. I lay with Caſſio lately,
And being troubled with a raging tooth,
I could not ſleepe. There are a kinde of men,
So looſe of Soule, that in their ſleepes will mutter
Their Affayres: one of this kinde is Caſſio:
In ſleepe I heard him ſay, ſweet Deſdemona,
Let vs be wary, let vs hide our Loues,
And then (Sir) would he gripe, and wring my hand:
Cry, oh ſweet Creature: then kiſſe me hard,
As if he pluckt vp kiſſes by the rootes,
That grew vpon my lippes, laid his Leg ore my Thigh,
And ſigh, and kiſſe, and then cry curſed Fate,
That gaue thee to the Moore.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: O monſtrous! monſtrous!

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Nay, this was but his Dreame.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: But this denoted a fore-gone concluſion,
‘Tis a ſhrew’d doubt, though it be but a Dreame.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: And this may helpe to thicken other proofes,
That do demonſtrate thinly.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Ile teare her all to peeces.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Nay yet be wiſe; yet we ſee nothing done,
She may be honeſt yet: Tell me but this,
Haue you not ſometimes ſeene a Handkerchiefe
Spotted with Strawberries, in your wiues hand?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I gaue her ſuch a one: ‘twas my firſt gift.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I know not that: but ſuch a Handkerchiefe
(I am ſure it was your wiues) did I to day
See Caſſio wipe his Beard with.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: If it be that.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: If it be that, or any, it was hers.
It ſpeakes againſt her with the other proofes.

speech.speaker: Othel.
speech.line: O that the Slaue had forty thouſand liues:
One is too poore, too weake for my reuenge.
Now do I ſee ‘tis true. Looke heere Iago,
All my fond loue thus do I blow to Heauen. ‘Tis gone.
Ariſe blacke vengeance, from the hollow hell,
Yeeld vp (O Loue) thy Crowne, and hearted Throne
To tyrannous Hate. Swell boſome with thy fraught,
For ‘tis of Aſpickes tongues.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Yet be content.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Oh blood, blood, blood.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Patience I ſay: your minde may change.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Neuer Iago. Like to the Ponticke Sea,
Whoſe Icie Current, and compulſiue courſe,
Neu’r keepes retyring ebbe, but keepes due on
To the Proponticke, and the Helleſpont:
Euen ſo my bloody thoughts, with violent pace
Shall neu’r looke backe, neu’r ebbe to humble Loue,
Till that a capeable, and wide Reuenge
Swallow them vp. Now by yond Marble Heauen,
In the due reuerence of a Sacred vow,
I heere engage my words.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Do not riſe yet:
Witneſſe you euer-burning Lights aboue,
You Elements, that clip vs round about,
Witneſſe that heere Iago doth giue vp
The execution of his wit, hands, heart,
To wrong’d Othello’s Seruice. Let him command,
And to obey ſhall be in me remorſe,
What bloody buſineſſe euer.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I greet thy loue,
Not with vaine thanks, but with acceptance bounteous,
And will vpon the inſtant put thee too’t.
Within theſe three dayes let me heare thee ſay,
That Caſſio’s not aliue.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: My Friend is dead:
‘Tis done at your Requeſt.
But let her liue.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Damne her lewde Minx:
O damne her, damne her.
Come go with me a-part, I will withdraw
To furniſh me with ſome ſwift meanes of death
For the faire Diuell.
Now art thou my Lieutenant.

speech.speaker: Iago
speech.line: I am your owne for euer.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Do you know Sirrah, where Lieutenant Caſſio
lyes?

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: I dare not ſay he lies any where.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Why man?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: He’s a Soldier, and for me to ſay a Souldier lyes,
‘tis ſtabbing.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Go too: where lodges he?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: To tell you where he lodges, is to tel you where
I lye.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Can any thing be made of this?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I know not where he lodges, and for mee to de-
uiſe a lodging, and ſay he lies heere, or he lies there, were
to lye in mine owne throat.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Can you enquire him out? and be edified by re-
port?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I will Catechize the world for him, that is, make
Queſtions, and by them anſwer.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Seeke him, bidde him come hither: tell him, I
haue moou’d my Lord on his behalfe, and hope all will
be well.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: To do this, is within the compaſſe of mans Wit,
and therefore I will attempt the doing it.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Where ſhould I looſe the Handkerchiefe, Æ-

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: I know not Madam.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Beleeue me, I had rather haue loſt my purſe
Full of Cruzadœs. And but my Noble Moore
Is true of minde, and made of no ſuch baſeneſſe,
As iealious Creatures are, it were enough
To put him to ill-thinking.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Is he not iealious?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Who, he? I thinke the Sun where he was borne,
Drew all ſuch humors from him.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Looke where he comes.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I will not leaue him now, till Caſſio be
Call’d to him. How is’t with you, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Well my good Lady. Oh hardnes to diſſemble!
How do you, Deſdemona?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Well, my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Giue me your hand.
This hand is moiſt, my Lady.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: It hath felt no age, nor knowne no ſorrow.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: This argues fruitfulneſſe, and liberall heart:
Hot, hot, and moyſt. This hand of yours requires
A ſequeſter from Liberty: Faſting, and Prayer,
Much Caſtigation, Exerciſe deuout,
For heere’s a yong, and ſweating Diuell heere
That commonly rebels: ‘Tis a good hand,
A franke one.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: You may (indeed) ſay ſo:
For ‘twas that hand that gaue away my heart.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: A liberall hand. The hearts of old, gaue hands:
But our new Heraldry is hands, not hearts.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I cannot ſpeake of this:
Come, now your promiſe.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: What promiſe, Chucke?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I haue ſent to bid Caſſio come ſpeake with you.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I haue a ſalt and ſorry Rhewme offends me:
Lend me thy Handkerchiefe.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Heere my Lord.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: That which I gaue you.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I haue it not about me.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Not?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: No indeed, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: That’s a fault: That Handkerchiefe
Did an Ægyptian to my Mother giue:
She was a Charmer, and could almoſt read
The thoughts of people. She told her, while ſhe kept it,
’T would make her Amiable, and ſubdue my Father
Intirely to her loue: But if ſhe loſt it,
Or made a Guift of it, my Fathers eye
Should hold her loathed, and his Spirits ſhould hunt
After new Fancies. She dying, gaue it me,
And bid me (when my Fate would haue me Wiu’d)
To giue it her. I did ſo; and take heede on’t,
Make it a Darling, like your precious eye:
To looſe’t, or giue’t away, were ſuch perdition,
As nothing elſe could match.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Is’t poſſible?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: ‘Tis true: There’s Magicke in the web of it:
A Sybill that had numbred in the world
The Sun to courſe, two hundred compaſſes,
In her Prophetticke furie ſow’d the Worke:
The Wormes were hallowed, that did breede the Silke,
And it was dyde in Mummey, which the Skilfull
Conſeru’d of Maidens hearts.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Indeed? Is’t true?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Moſt veritable, therefore looke too’t well.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Then would to Heauen, that I had neuer ſeene’t?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Ha? wherefore?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Why do you ſpeake ſo ſtartingly, and raſh?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Is’t loſt? Is’t gon? Speak, is’t out o’th’ way?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Bleſſe vs.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Say you?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: It is not loſt: but what and if it were?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: How?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I ſay it is not loſt.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Fetcht, let me ſee’t.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Why ſo I can: but I will not now:
This is a tricke to put me from my ſuite,
Pray you let Caſſio be receiu’d againe.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Fetch me the Handkerchiefe,
My minde miſ-giues.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Come, come: you’l neuer meete a more ſuffici-
ent man.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: The Handkerchiefe.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: A man that all his time
Hath founded his good Fortunes on your loue;
Shar’d dangers with you.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: The Handkerchiefe.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Inſooth, you are too blame.

speech.speaker: Oth
speech.line: Away.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Is not this man iealious?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I neu’r ſaw this before.
Sure, there’s ſome wonder in this Handkerchiefe,
I am moſt vnhappy in the loſſe of it.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: ‘Tis not a yeare or two ſhewes vs a man:
They are all but Stomackes, and we all but Food,
They eate vs hungerly, and when they are full
They belch vs.
Looke you, Caſſio and my Husband.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: There is no other way: ‘tis ſhe muſt doo’t:
And loe the happineſſe: go, and importune her.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: How now (good Caſſio) what’s the newes with
you?

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: Madam, my former ſuite. I do beſeech you,
That by your vertuous meanes, I may againe
Exiſt, and be a member of his loue,
Whom I, with all the Office of my heart
Intirely honour, I would not be delayd.
If my offence, be of ſuch mortall kinde,
That nor my Seruice paſt, nor preſent Sorrowes,
Nor purpos’d merit in futurity,
Can ranſome me into his loue againe,
But to know ſo, muſt be my benefit:
So ſhall I cloath me in a forc’d content,
And ſhut my ſelfe vp in ſome other courſe
To Fortunes Almes.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Alas (thrice-gentle Caſſio)
My Aduocation is not now in Tune;
My Lord, is not my Lord; nor ſhould I know him,
Were he in Fauour, as in Humour alter’d.
So helpe me euery ſpirit ſanƈtified,
As I haue ſpoken for you all my beſt,
And ſtood within the blanke of his diſpleaſure
For my free ſpeech. You muſt awhile be patient:
What I can do, I will: and more I will
Then for my ſelfe, I dare. Let that ſuffice you.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Is my Lord angry?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: He went hence but now:
And certainly in ſtrange vnquietneſſe.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Can he be angry? I haue ſeen the Cannon
When it hath blowne his Rankes into the Ayre,
And like the Diuell from his very Arme
Puff’t his owne Brother: And is he angry?
Something of moment then: I will go meet him,
There’s matter in’t indeed, if he be angry.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I prythee do ſo. Something ſure of State,
Either from Venice, or ſome vnhatch’d praƈtiſe
Made demonſtrable heere in Cyprus, to him,
Hath pudled his cleare Spirit: and in ſuch caſes,
Mens Natures wrangle with inferiour things,
Though great ones are their obieƈt. ‘Tis euen ſo.
For let our finger ake, and it endues
Our other healthfull members, euen to a ſenſe
Of paine. Nay, we muſt thinke men are not Gods,
Nor of them looke for ſuch obſeruancie
As fits the Bridall. Beſhrew me much, Æmilia,
I was (vnhandſome Warrior, as I am)
Arraigning his vnkindneſſe with my ſoule:
But now I finde, I had ſuborn’d the Witneſſe,
And he’s Indited falſely.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Pray heauen it bee
State matters, as you thinke, and no Conception,
Nor no Iealious Toy, concerning you.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Alas the day, I neuer gaue him cauſe.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: But Iealious ſoules will not be anſwer’d ſo;
They are not euer iealious for the cauſe,
But iealious, for they’re iealious. It is a Monſter
Begot vpon it ſelfe, borne on it ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Heauen keepe the Monſter from Othello’s mind.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Lady, Amen.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I will go ſeeke him. Caſſio, walke heere about:
If I doe finde him fit, Ile moue your ſuite,
And ſeeke to effeƈt it to my vttermoſt.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: I humbly thanke your Ladyſhip.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: ‘Saue you (Friend Caſſio.)

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: What make you from home?
How is’t with you, my moſt faire Bianca?
Indeed (ſweet Loue) I was comming to your houſe.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: And I was going to your Lodging, Caſſio.
What? keepe a weeke away? Seuen dayes, and Nights?
Eight ſcore eight houres? And Louers abſent howres
More tedious then the Diall, eight ſcore times?
Oh weary reck’ning.

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: Pardon me, Bianca:
I haue this while with leaden thoughts beene preſt,
But I ſhall in a more continuate time
Strike off this ſcore of abſence. Sweet Bianca
Take me this worke out.

speech.speaker: Bianca.
speech.line: Oh Caſſio, whence came this?
This is ſome Token from a newer Friend,
To the felt-Abſence: now I feele a Cauſe:
Is’t come to this? Well, well.

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: Go too, woman:
Throw your vilde geſſes in the Diuels teeth,
From whence you haue them. You are iealious now,
That this is from ſome Miſtris, ſome remembrance;
No, in good troth Bianca.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Why, who’s is it?

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: I know not neither:
I found it in my Chamber,
I like the worke well; Ere it be demanded
(As like enough it will) I would haue it coppied:
Take it, and doo’t, and leaue me for this time.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Leaue you? Wherefore?

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: I do attend heere on the Generall,
And thinke it no addition, nor my wiſh
To haue him ſee me woman’d.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Why, I pray you?

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: Not that I loue you not.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: But that you do not loue me.
I pray you bring me on the way a little,
And ſay, if I ſhall ſee you ſoone at night?

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: ‘Tis but a little way that I can bring you,
For I attend heere: But Ile ſee you ſoone.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: ‘Tis very good: I muſt be circumſtanc’d.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Will you thinke ſo?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Thinke ſo, Iago?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: What, to kiſſe in priuate?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: An vnauthoriz’d kiſſe?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Or to be naked with her Friend in bed,
An houre, or more, not meaning any harme?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Naked in bed (Iago) and not meane harme?
It is hypocriſie againſt the Diuell:
They that meane vertuouſly, and yet do ſo,
The Diuell their vertue tempts, and they tempt Heauen.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: If they do nothing, ‘tis a Veniall ſlip:
But if I giue my wife a Handkerchiefe.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: What then?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Why then ‘tis hers (my Lord) and being hers,
She may (I thinke) beſtow’t on any man.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: She is Proteƈtreſſe of her honor too:
May ſhe giue that?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Her honor is an Eſſence that’s not ſeene,
They haue it very oft, that haue it not.
But for the Handkerchiefe.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: By heauen, I would moſt gladly haue forgot it:
Thou ſaidſt (oh, it comes ore my memorie,
As doth the Rauen o’re the infeƈtious houſe:
Boading to all) he had my Handkerchiefe.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I: what of that?

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: That’s not ſo good now.

speech.speaker: Iag.
speech.line: What if I had ſaid, I had ſeene him do you wrong?
Or heard him ſay (as Knaues be ſuch abroad,
Who hauing by their owne importunate ſuit,
Or voluntary dotage of ſome Miſtris,
Conuinced or ſupply’d them, cannot chuſe
But they muſt blab.)

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Hath he ſaid any thing?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: He hath (my Lord) but be you well aſſur’d,
No more then he’le vn-ſweare.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: What hath he ſaid?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Why, that he did: I know not what he did.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: What? What?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Lye.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: With her?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: With her? On her: what you will.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Lye with her? lye on her? We ſay lye on her,
when they be-lye-her. Lye with her: that’s fullſome:
Handkerchiefe: Confeſſions: Handkerchiefe. To con-
feſſe, and be hang’d for his labour. Firſt, to be hang’d,
and then to confeſſe: I tremble at it. Nature would not
inueſt her ſelfe in ſuch ſhadowing paſſion, without ſome
Inſtruƈtion. It is not words that ſhakes me thus, (piſh)
Noſes, Eares, and Lippes: is’t poſſible. Confeſſe? Hand-
kerchiefe? O diuell.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Worke on,
My Medicine workes. Thus credulous Fooles are caught,
And many worthy, and chaſt Dames euen thus,
(All guiltleſſe) meete reproach: what hoa? My Lord?
My Lord, I ſay: Othello.
How now Caſſio?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: My Lord is falne into an Epilepſie,
This is his ſecond Fit: he had one yeſterday.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Rub him about the Temples.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: The Lethargie muſt haue his quyet courſe:
If not, he foames at mouth: and by and by
Breakes out to ſauage madneſſe. Looke, he ſtirres:
Do you withdraw your ſelfe a little while,
He will recouer ſtraight: when he is gone,
I would on great occaſion, ſpeake with you.
How is it Generall? Haue you not hurt your head?

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Doſt thou mocke me?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I mocke you not, by Heauen:
Would you would beare your Fortune like a Man.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: A Horned man’s a Monſter, and a Beaſt.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Ther’s many a Beaſt then in a populous Citty,
And many a ciuill Monſter.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Did he confeſſe it?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Good Sir, be a man:
Thinke euery bearded fellow that’s but yoak’d
May draw with you. There’s Millions now aliue,
That nightly lye in thoſe vnproper beds,
Which they dare ſweare peculiar. Your caſe is better.
Oh, ‘tis the ſpight of hell, the Fiends Arch-mock,
To lip a wanton in a ſecure Cowch;
And to ſuppoſe her chaſt. No, let me know,
And knowing what I am, I know what ſhe ſhallbe.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Oh, thou art wiſe: ‘tis certaine.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Stand you a while apart,
Confine your ſelfe but in a patient Liſt,
Whil’ſt you were heere, o’re-whelmed with your griefe
(A paſſion moſt reſulting ſuch a man)
Caſſio came hither: I ſhifted him away,
And layd good ſcuſes vpon your Extaſie,
Bad him anon returne: and heere ſpeake with me,
The which he promis’d. Do but encaue your ſelfe,
And marke the Fleeres, the Gybes, and notable Scornes
That dwell in euery Region of his face.
For I will make him tell the Tale anew;
Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when
He hath, and is againe to cope your wife.
I ſay, but marke his geſture: marry Patience,
Or I ſhall ſay y’are all in all in Spleene,
And nothing of a man.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Do’ſt thou heare, Iago,
I will be found moſt cunning in my Patience:
But (do’ſt thou heare) moſt bloody.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: That’s not amiſſe,
But yet keepe time in all: will you withdraw?
Now will I queſtion Caſſio of Bianca,
A Huſwife that by ſelling her deſires
Buyes her ſelfe Bread, and Cloath. It is a Creature
That dotes on Caſſio, (as ‘tis the Strumpets plague
To be-guile many, and be be-guil’d by one)
He, when he heares of her, cannot reſtraine
From the exceſſe of Laughter. Heere he comes.
As he ſhall ſmile, Othello ſhall go mad:
And his vnbookiſh Ielouſie muſt conſerue
Poore Caſſio’s ſmiles, geſtures, and light behauiours
Quite in the wrong. How do you Lieutenant?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: The worſer, that you giue me the addition,
Whoſe want euen killes me.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Ply Deſdemona well, and you are ſure on’t:
Now, if this Suit lay in Bianca’s dowre,
How quickely ſhould you ſpeed?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Alas poore Caitiffe.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Looke how he laughes already.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I neuer knew woman loue man ſo.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Alas poore Rogue, I thinke indeed ſhe loues me.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Now he denies it faintly: and laughes it out.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Do you heare Caſſio?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Now he importunes him
To tell it o’re: go too, well ſaid, well ſaid.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: She giues it out, that you ſhall marry her.
Do you intend it?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Do ye triumph, Romaine? do you triumph?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: I marry. What? A cuſtomer; prythee beare
Some Charitie to my wit, do not thinke it
So vnwholeſome. Ha, ha, ha.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: So, ſo, ſo, ſo: they laugh, that winnes.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Why the cry goes, that you marry her.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Prythee ſay true.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I am a very Villaine elſe.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Haue you ſcoar’d me? Well.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: This is the Monkeys owne giuing out:
She is perſwaded I will marry her
Out of her owne loue & flattery, not out of my promiſe.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Iago becomes me: now he begins the ſtory.

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: She was heere euen now: ſhe haunts me in e-
uery place. I was the other day talking on the Sea-
banke with certaine Venetians, and thither comes the
Bauble, and falls me thus about my neck.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Crying oh deere Caſſio, as it were: his ieſture im-
ports it.

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: So hangs, and lolls, and weepes vpon me:
So ſhakes, and pulls me. Ha, ha, ha.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Now he tells how ſhe pluckt him to my Cham-
ber: oh, I ſee that noſe of yours, but not that dogge, I
ſhall throw it to.

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: Well, I muſt leaue her companie.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Before me: looke where ſhe comes.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: ‘Tis ſuch another Fitchew: marry a perfum’d one?
What do you meane by this haunting of me?

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Let the diuell, and his dam haunt you: what
did you meane by that ſame Handkerchiefe, you gaue
me euen now? I was a fine Foole to take it: I muſt take
out the worke? A likely piece of worke, that you ſhould
finde it in your Chamber, and know not who left it there.
This is ſome Minxes token, & I muſt take out the worke?
There, giue it your Hobbey-horſe, whereſoeuer you had
it, Ile take out no worke on’t.

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: How now, my ſweete Bianca?
How now? How now?

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: By Heauen, that ſhould be my Handkerchiefe.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: If you’le come to ſupper to night you may, if
you will not, come when you are next prepar’d for.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: After her: after her.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: I muſt, ſhee’l rayle in the ſtreets elſe.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Will you ſup there?

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: Yes, I intend ſo.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Well, I may chance to ſee you: for I would ve-
ry faine ſpeake with you.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Prythee come: will you?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Go too; ſay no more.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: How ſhall I murther him, Iago.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Did you perceiue how he laugh’d at his vice?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Oh, Iago.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: And did you ſee the Handkerchiefe?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Was that mine?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Yours by this hand: and to ſee how he prizes
the fooliſh woman your wife: ſhe gaue it him and, he
hath giu’n it his whore.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I would haue him nine yeeres a killing:
A fine woman, a faire woman, a ſweete woman?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Nay, you muſt forget that.

speech.speaker: Othello.
speech.line: I, let her rot and periſh, and be damn’d to
night, for ſhe ſhall not liue. No, my heart is turn’d to
ſtone: I ſtrike it, and it hurts my hand. Oh, the world
hath not a ſweeter Creature: ſhe might lye by an Em-
perours ſide, and command him Taſkes.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Nay, that’s not your way.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Hang her, I do but ſay what ſhe is: ſo delicate
with her Needle: an admirable Muſitian. Oh ſhe will
ſing the Sauageneſſe out of a Beare: of ſo high and plen-
teous wit, and inuention?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: She’s the worſe for all this.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Oh, a thouſand, a thouſand times:
And then of ſo gentle a condition?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I too gentle.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Nay that’s certaine:
But yet the pitty of it, Iago: oh Iago, the pitty of it
Iago.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: If you are ſo fond ouer her iniquitie: giue her
pattent to offend, for if it touch not you, it comes neere
no body.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I will chop her into Meſſes: Cuckold me?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Oh, ‘tis foule in her.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: With mine Officer?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: That’s fouler.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Get me ſome poyſon, Iago, this night. Ile not
expoſtulate with her: leaſt her body and beautie vnpro-
uide my mind againe: this night Iago.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Do it not with poyſon, ſtrangle her in her bed,
Euen the bed ſhe hath contaminated.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Good, good:
The Iuſtice of it pleaſes: very good.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: And for Caſſio, let me be his vndertaker:
You ſhall heare more by midnight.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Excellent good: What Trumpet is that ſame?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I warrant ſomething from Venice,
‘Tis Lodouico, this, comes from the Duke.
See, your wife’s with him.

speech.speaker: Lodo.
speech.line: Saue you worthy Generall.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: With all my heart Sir.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: The Duke, and the Senators of Venice greet you.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: I kiſſe the Inſtrument of their pleaſures.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: And what’s the newes, good cozen Lodouico?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I am very glad to ſee you Signior:
Welcome to Cyprus.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: I thanke you: how do’s Lieutenant Caſſio?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Liues Sir,

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Cozen, there’s falne betweene him, & my Lord,
An vnkind breach: but you ſhall make all well.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Are you ſure of that?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: My Lord?

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: This faile you not to do, as you will—

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: He did not call: he’s buſie in the paper,
Is there deuiſion ‘twixt my Lord, and Caſſio?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: A moſt vnhappy one: I would do much
T’ attone, them, for the loue I beare to Caſſio.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Fire, and brimeſtone.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Are you wiſe?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: What is he angrie?

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: May be the Letter mou’d him.
For as I thinke, they do command him home,
Deputing Caſſio in his Gouernment.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Truſt me, I am glad on’t.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Indeed?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: My Lord?

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: I am glad to ſee you mad.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Why, ſweete Othello?

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Diuell.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I haue not deſeru’d this.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: My Lord, this would not be beleeu’d in Venice,
Though I ſhould ſweare I ſaw’t. ‘Tis very much,
Make her amends: ſhe weepes.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Oh diuell, diuell:
If that the Earth could teeme with womans teares,
Each drop ſhe falls, would proue a Crocodile:
Out of my ſight.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I will not ſtay to offend you.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Truely obedient Lady:
I do beſeech your Lordſhip call her backe.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Miſtris.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: What would you with her, Sir?

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Who I, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: I, you did wiſh, that I would make her turne:
Sir, ſhe can turne, and turne: and yet go on
And turne againe. And ſhe can weepe, Sir, weepe.
And ſhe’s obedient: as you ſay obedient.
Very obedient: proceed you in your teares.
Concerning this Sir, (oh well-painted paſſion)
I am commanded home: get you away:
Ile ſend for you anon. Sir I obey the Mandate,
And will returne to Venice. Hence, auaunt:
Caſſio ſhall haue my Place. And Sir, to night
I do entreat, that we may ſup together.
You are welcome Sir to Cyprus.
Goates, and Monkeys.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Is this the Noble Moore, whom our full Senate
Call all in all ſufficient? Is this the Nature
Whom Paſſion could not ſhake? Whoſe ſolid vertue
The ſhot of Accident, nor dart of Chance
Could neither graze, nor pierce?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: He is much chang’d.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Are his wits ſafe? Is he not light of Braine?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: He’s that he is: I may not breath my cenſure.
What he might be: if what he might, he is not,
I would to heauen he were.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: What? Strike his wife?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: ‘Faith that was not ſo well: yet would I knew
That ſtroke would proue the worſt.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Is it his vſe?
Or did the Letters, worke vpon his blood,
And new create his fault?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Alas, alas:
It is not honeſtie in me to ſpeake
What I haue ſeene, and knowne. You ſhall obſerue him,
And his owne courſes will denote him ſo,
That I may ſaue my ſpeech: do but go after
And marke how he continues.

speech.speaker: Lod
speech.line: I am ſorry that I am deceiu’d in him.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: You haue ſeene nothing then?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Nor euer heard: nor euer did ſuſpeƈt.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Yes, you haue ſeene Caſſio, and ſhe together.

speech.speaker: Æmi.
speech.line: But then I ſaw no harme: and then I heard,
Each ſyllable that breath made vp betweene them.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: What? Did they neuer whiſper?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Neuer my Lord.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Nor ſend you out o’th’ way?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Neuer.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: To fetch her Fan, her Gloues, her Maſk, nor nothing?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Neuer my Lord.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: That’s ſtrange.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: I durſt (my Lord) to wager, ſhe is honeſt:
Lay downe my Soule at ſtake: If you thinke other,
Remoue your thought. It doth abuſe your boſome:
If any wretch haue put this in your head,
Let Heauen requit it with the Serpents curſe,
For if ſhe be not honeſt, chaſte, and true,
There’s no man happy. The pureſt of their Wiues
Is foule as Slander.

speech.speaker: Othe
speech.line: Bid her come hither: go.
She ſaies enough: yet ſhe’s a ſimple Baud
That cannot ſay as much. This is a ſubtile Whore:
A Cloſſet Locke and Key of Villanous Secrets,
And yet ſhe’le kneele, and pray: I haue ſeene her do’t.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: My Lord, what is your will?

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Pray you Chucke come hither.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: What is your pleaſure?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Let me ſee your eyes: looke in my face.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: What horrible Fancie’s this?

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Some of your Funƈtion Miſtris:
Leaue Procreants alone, and ſhut the doore:
Cough, or cry hem; if any body come:
Your Myſtery, your Myſtery: May diſpatch.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Vpon my knee, what doth your ſpeech import?
I vnderſtand a Fury in your words.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Why? What art thou?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Your wife my Lord: your true and loyall wife.

speech.speaker: Othello.
speech.line: Come ſweare it: damne thy ſelfe, leaſt
being like one of Heauen, the diuells themſelues ſhould
feare to ceaze thee. Therefore be double damn’d: ſweare
thou art honeſt.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Heauen doth truely know it.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Heauen truely knowes, that thou art falſe as hell.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: To whom my Lord?
With whom? How am I falſe?

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Ah Deſdemon, away, away, away.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Alas the heauy day: why do you weepe?
Am I the motiue of theſe teares my Lord?
If happely you my Father do ſuſpeƈt,
An Inſtrument of this your calling backe,
Lay not your blame on me: if you haue loſt him,
I haue loſt him too.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Had it pleas’d Heauen,
To try me with Affliƈtion, had they rain’d
All kind of Sores, and Shames on my bare-head:
Steep’d me in pouertie to the very lippes.
Giuen to Captiuitie, me, and my vtmoſt hopes,
I ſhould haue found in ſome place of my Soule
A drop of patience. But alas, to make me
The fixed Figure for the time of Scorne,
To point his ſlow, and mouing finger at.
Yet could I beare that too, well, very well:
But there where I haue garnerd vp my heart,
Where either I muſt liue, or beare no life,
The Fountaine from the which my currant runnes,
Or elſe dries vp: to be diſcarded thence,
Or keepe it as a Ceſterne, for foule Toades
To knot and gender in. Turne thy complexion there:
Patience, thou young and Roſe-lip’d Cherubin,
I heere looke grim as hell.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I hope my Noble Lord eſteemes me honeſt.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Oh I, as Sommer Flyes are in the Shambles,
That quicken euen with blowing. Oh thou weed:
Who art ſo louely faire, and ſmell’ſt ſo ſweete,
That the Senſe akes at thee,
Would thou had’ſt neuer bin borne.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Alas, what ignorant ſin haue I committed?

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Was this faire Paper? This moſt goodly Booke
Made to write Whore vpon? What commited,
Committed? Oh, thou publicke Commoner,
I ſhould make very Forges of my cheekes,
That would to Cynders burne vp Modeſtie,
Did I but ſpeake thy deedes. What commited?
Heauen ſtoppes the Noſe at it, and the Moone winks:
The baudy winde that kiſſes all it meetes,
Is huſh’d within the hollow Myne of Earth
And will not hear’t. What commited?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: By Heauen you do me wrong.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Are not you a Strumpet?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: No, as I am a Chriſtian.
If to preſerue this veſſell for my Lord,
From any other foule vnlawfull touch
Be not to be a Strumpet, I am none.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: What, not a Whore?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: No, as I ſhall be ſau’d.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: Is’t poſſible?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Oh Heauen forgiue vs.

speech.speaker: Othe.
speech.line: I cry you mercy then.
I tooke you for that cunning Whore of Venice,
That married with Othello. You Miſtris,
That haue the office oppoſite to Saint Peter,
And keepes the gate of hell. You, you: I you.
We haue done our courſe: there’s money for your paines:
I pray you turne the key, and keepe our counſaile.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Alas, what do’s this Gentleman conceiue?
How do you Madam? how do you my good Lady?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Faith, halfe a ſleepe.

speech.speaker: Æmi.
speech.line: Good Madam,
What’s the matter with my Lord?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: With who?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Why, with my Lord, Madam?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Who is thy Lord?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: He that is yours, ſweet Lady.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I haue none: do not talke to me, Æmilia,
I cannot weepe: nor anſweres haue I none,
But what ſhould go by water. Prythee to night,
Lay on my bed my wedding ſheetes, remember,
And call thy huſband hither.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Heere’s a change indeed.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: ‘Tis meete I ſhould be vs’d ſo: very meete.
How haue I bin behau’d, that he might ſticke
The ſmall’ſt opinion on my leaſt miſvſe?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: What is your pleaſure Madam?
How is’t with you?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I cannot tell: thoſe that do teach yong Babes
Do it with gentle meanes, and eaſie taſkes.
He might haue chid me ſo; for in good faith
I am a Child to chiding.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: What is the matter Lady?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Alas (Iago) my Lord hath ſo bewhor’d her,
Throwne ſuch diſpight, and heauy termes vpon her
That true hearts cannot beare it.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Am I that name, Iago?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: What name (faire Lady?)

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Such as ſhe ſaid my Lord did ſay I was.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: He call’d her whore: a Begger in his drinke:
Could not haue laid ſuch termes vpon his Callet.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Why did he ſo?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I do not know: I am ſure I am none ſuch.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Do not weepe, do not weepe: alas the day.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Hath ſhe forſooke ſo many Noble Matches?
Her Father? And her Country? And her Friends?
To be call’d Whore? Would it not make one weepe?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: It is my wretched Fortune.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Beſhrew him for’t:
How comes this Tricke vpon him?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Nay, Heauen doth know.

speech.speaker: Æmi.
speech.line: I will be hang’d, if ſome eternall Villaine,
Some buſie and inſinuating Rogue,
Some cogging, cozening Slaue, to get ſome Office,
Haue not deuis’d this Slander: I will be hang’d elſe.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Fie, there is no ſuch man: it is impoſſible.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: If any ſuch there be, Heauen pardon him.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: A halter pardon him:
And hell gnaw his bones.
Why ſhould he call her Whore?
Who keepes her companie?
What Place? What Time?
What Forme? What liklyhood?
The Moore’s abus’d by ſome moſt villanous Knaue,
Some baſe notorious Knaue, ſome ſcuruy Fellow.
Oh Heauens, that ſuch companions thou’d’ſt vnfold,
And put in euery honeſt hand a whip
To laſh the Raſcalls naked through the world,
Euen from the Eaſt to th’ Weſt.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Speake within doore.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Oh fie vpon them: ſome ſuch Squire he was
That turn’d your wit, the ſeamy-ſide without,
And made you to ſuſpeƈt me with the Moore.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: You are a Foole: go too.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Alas Iago,
What ſhall I do to win my Lord againe?
Good Friend, go to him: for by this light of Heauen,
I know not how I loſt him. Heere I kneele:
If ere my will did treſpaſſe ’gainſt his Loue,
Either in diſcourſe of thought, or aƈtuall deed,
Or that mine Eyes, mine Eares, or any Sence
Delighted them: or any other Forme.
Or that I do not yet, and euer did,
And euer will, (though he do ſhake me off
To beggerly diuorcement) Loue him deerely,
Comfort forſweare me. Vnkindneſſe may do much,
And his vnkindneſſe may defeat my life,
But neuer taynt my Loue. I cannot ſay Whore,
It do’s abhorre me now I ſpeake the word,
To do the Aƈt, that might the addition earne,
Not the worlds Maſſe of vanitie could make me.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I pray you be content: ‘tis but his humour:
The buſineſſe of the State do’s him offence.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: If ’twere no other.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: It is but ſo, I warrant,
Hearke how theſe Inſtruments ſummon to ſupper:
The Meſſengers of Venice ſtaies the meate,
Go in, and weepe not: all things ſhall be well.
How now Rodorigo?

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: I do not finde
That thou deal’ſt iuſtly with me.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: What in the contrarie?

speech.speaker: Rodori.
speech.line: Euery day thou dafts me with ſome deuiſe
Iago, and rather, as it ſeemes to me now, keep’ſt from
me all conueniencie, then ſupplieſt me with the leaſt ad-
uantage of hope: I will indeed no longer endure it. Nor
am I yet perſwaded to put vp in peace, what already I
haue fooliſhly ſuffred.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Will you heare me Rodorigo?

speech.speaker: Rodori.
speech.line: I haue heard too much: and your words and
Performances are no kin together.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: You charge me moſt vniuſtly.

speech.speaker: Rodo.
speech.line: With naught but truth: I haue wasted my
ſelfe out of my meanes. The Iewels you haue had from
me to deliuer Deſdemona, would halfe haue corrupted a
Votariſt. You haue told me ſhe hath receiu’d them,
and return’d me expeƈtations and comforts of ſodaine
reſpeƈt, and acquaintance, but I finde none.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Well, go too: very well.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Very well, go too: I cannot go too, (man) nor
‘tis not very well. Nay I think it is ſcuruy: and begin to
finde my ſelfe fopt in it.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Very well.

speech.speaker: Rodor.
speech.line: I tell you, ‘tis not very well: I will make my
ſelfe knowne to Deſdemona. If ſhe will returne me my
Iewels, I will giue ouer my Suit, and repent my vnlaw-
full ſolicitation. If not, aſſure your ſelfe, I will ſeeke
ſatisfaƈtion of you.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: You haue ſaid now.

speech.speaker: Rodo.
speech.line: I: and ſaid nothing but what I proteſt intend-
ment of doing.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Why, now I ſee there’s mettle in thee: and
euen from this inſtant do build on thee a better o-
pinion then euer before: giue me thy hand Rodorigo.
Thou haſt taken againſt me a moſt iuſt excepti-
on: but yet I proteſt I haue dealt moſt direƈtly in thy
Affaire.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: It hath not appeer’d.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I grant indeed it hath not appeer’d: and
your ſuſpition is not without wit and iudgement.
But Rodorigo, if thou haſt that in thee indeed, which
I haue greater reaſon to beleeue now then euer (I
meane purpoſe, Courage, and Valour) this night
ſhew it. If thou the next night following enioy not
Deſdemona, take me from this world with Treache-
rie, and deuiſe Engines for my life.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Well: what is it? Is it within, reaſon and com-
paſſe?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Sir, there is eſpeciall Commiſſion come from
Venice to depute Caſſio in Othello’s place.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Is that true? Why then Othello and Deſdemona
returne againe to Venice.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Oh no: he goes into Mauritania and taketh
away with him the faire Deſdemona, vnleſſe his a-
bode be lingred heere by ſome accident. Where-
in none can be ſo determinate, as the remouing of
Caſſio.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: How do you meane remouing him?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Why, by making him vncapable of Othello’s
place: knocking out his braines.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: And that you would haue me to do.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I: if you dare do your ſelfe a profit, and a
right. He ſups to night with a Harlotry: and thither
will I go to him. He knowes not yet of his Honourable
Fortune, if you will watch his going thence (which
I will faſhion to fall out betweene twelue and one)
you may take him at your pleaſure. I will be neere
to ſecond your Attempt, and he ſhall fall betweene
vs. Come, ſtand not amaz’d at it, but go along with
me: I will ſhew you ſuch a neceſſitie in his death, that
you ſhall thinke your ſelfe bound to put it on him. It
is now high ſupper time: and the night growes to waſt.
About it.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: I will heare further reaſon for this.

speech.speaker: Iago
speech.line: And you ſhalbe ſatisfi’d.

scene.stagedir: Enter Othello, Lodouico, Deſdemona, Æmilia, and Atendants.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: I do beſeech you Sir, trouble your ſelfe no further.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Oh pardon me: ‘twill do me good to walke.

speech.speaker: Lodoui.
speech.line: Madam, good night: I humbly thanke your
Ladyſhip.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Your Honour is moſt welcome.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Will you walke Sir? Oh Deſdemona.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Othello.
speech.line: Get you to bed on th’ inſtant, I will be re-
turn’d forthwith: diſmiſſe your Attendant there: look’t
be done.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I will my Lord.

speech.speaker: Æm.
speech.line: How goes it now? He lookes gentler then he did.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: He ſaies he will returne incontinent,
And hath commanded me to go to bed,
And bid me to diſmiſſe you.

speech.speaker: Æmi.
speech.line: Diſmiſſe me?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: It was his bidding: therefore good Æmilia,
Giue me my nightly wearing, and adieu.
We muſt not now diſpleaſe him.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: I, would you had neuer ſeene him.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: So would not I: my loue doth ſo approue him,
That euen his ſtubborneſſe, his checks, his frownes,
(Prythee vn-pin me) haue grace and fauour.

speech.speaker: Æmi.
speech.line: I haue laid thoſe Sheetes you bad me on the bed.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: All’s one: good Father, how fooliſh are our minds?
If I do die before, prythee ſhrow’d me
In one of theſe ſame Sheetes.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Come, come: you talke.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: My Mother had a Maid call’d Barbarie,
She was in loue: and he ſhe lou’d prou’d mad,
And did forſake her. She had a Song of Willough,
An old thing ‘twas: but it expreſs’d her Fortune,
And ſhe dy’d ſinging it. That Song to night,
Will not go from my mind: I haue much to do,
But to go hang my head all at one ſide
And ſing it like poore Brabarie: prythee diſpatch.

speech.speaker: Æmi.
speech.line: Shall I go fetch your Night-gowne?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: No, vn-pin me here,
This Lodouico is a proper man.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: A very handsome man.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: He ſpeakes well.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: I know a Lady in Venice would haue walk’d
barefoot to Paleſtine for a touch of his nether lip.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: The poore Soule ſat ſinging, by a Sicamour tree.
Sing all a greene Willough:
Her hand on her boſome her head on her knee,
Sing Willough, Willough, Willough.
The freſh Streames ran by her, and murmur’d her moanes
Sing Willough, &c.
Her ſalt teares fell from her, and ſoftned the ſtones,
Sing Willough, &c. (Lay by theſe)
Willough, Willough. (Prythee high thee: he’le come anon)
Sing all a greene Willough muſt be my Garland.
Let no body blame him, his ſcorne I approue.
(Nay that’s not next. Harke, who is’t that knocks?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: It’s the wind.

speech.speaker: Deſ.

line.italic: I call’d my Loue falſe Loue: but what ſaid he then?
Sing Willough, &c.
If I court mo women, you’le couch with mo men.

speech.line: So get thee gone, good night: mine eyes do itch:
Doth that boade weeping?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: ‘Tis neyther heere, nor there.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I haue heard it ſaid ſo. O theſe Men, theſe men!
Do’ſt thou in conſcience thinke (tell me Æmilia)
That there be women do abuſe their huſbands
In ſuch groſſe kinde?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: There be ſome ſuch, no queſtion.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Would’ſt thou do ſuch a deed for all the world?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Why, would not you?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: No, by this Heauenly light.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Nor I neither, by this Heauenly light:
I might doo’t as well i’th’ darke.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Would’ſt thou do ſuch a deed for al the world?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: The world’s a huge thing:
It is a great price, for a ſmall vice.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Introth, I thinke thou would’ſt not.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Introth I thinke I ſhould, and vndoo’t when
I had done. Marry, I would not doe ſuch a thing for a
ioynt Ring, nor for meaſures of Lawne, nor for Gownes,
Petticoats, nor Caps, nor any petty exhibition. But for
all the whole world: why, who would not make her hus-
band a Cuckold, to make him a Monarch? I ſhould ven-
ture Purgatory for’t.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Beſhrew me, if I would do ſuch a wrong
For the whole world.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Why, the wrong is but a wrong i’th’ world;
and hauing the world for your labour, ‘tis a wrong in
your owne world, and you might quickly make it right.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I do not thinke there is any ſuch woman.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Yes, a dozen: and as many to’th’ vantage, as
would ſtore the world they plaid for.
But I do thinke it is their Husbands faults
If Wiues do fall: (Say, that they ſlacke their duties,
And powre our Treaſures into forraigne laps;
Or elſe breake out in peeuiſh Iealouſies,
Throwing reſtraint vpon vs: Or ſay they ſtrike vs,
Or ſcant our former hauing in deſpight)
Why we haue galles: and though we haue ſome Grace,
Yet haue we ſome Reuenge. Let Husbands know,
Their wiues haue ſenſe like them: They ſee, and ſmell,
And haue their Palats both for ſweet, and ſowre,
As Husbands haue. What is it that they do,
When they change vs for others? Is it Sport?
I thinke it is: and doth Affeƈtion breed it?
I thinke it doth. Is’t Frailty that thus erres?
It is ſo too. And haue not we Affeƈtions?
Deſires for Sport? and Frailty, as men haue?
Then let them vſe vs well: elſe let them know,
The illes we do, their illes inſtruƈt vs ſo.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Good night, good night:
Heauen me ſuch vſes ſend,
Not to picke bad, from bad; but by bad, mend.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Heere, ſtand behinde this Barke,
Straight will he come:
Weare thy good Rapier bare, and put it home:
Quicke, quicke, feare nothing; Ile be at thy Elbow,
It makes vs, or it marres vs, thinke on that,
And fixe moſt firme thy Reſolution.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Be neere at hand, I may miſcarry in’t.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Heere, at thy hand: Be bold, & take thy ſtand.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: I haue no great deuotion to the deed,
And yet he hath giuen me ſatisfying Reaſons:
‘Tis but a man gone. Forth my Sword: he dies.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I haue rub’d this yong Quat almoſt to the ſenſe,
And he growes angry. Now, whether he kill Caſſio,
Or Caſſio him, or each do kill the other,
Euery way makes my gaine. Liue Rodorigo,
He calles me to a reſtitution large
Of Gold, and Iewels, that I bob’d from him,
As Guifts to Deſdemona.
It muſt not be: If Caſſio do remaine,
He hath a dayly beauty in his life,
That makes me vgly: and beſides, the Moore
May vnfold me to him: there ſtand I in much perill:
No, he muſt dye. But ſo, I heard him comming.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: I know his gate, ‘tis he: Villaine thou dyeſt.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: That thruſt had beene mine enemy indeed,
But that my Coate is better then thou know’ſt:
I will make proofe of thine.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Oh, I am ſlaine.

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: I am maym’d for euer:
Helpe hoa: Murther, murther.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: The voyce of Caſſio. Iago keepes his word.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: O Villaine that I am.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: It is euen ſo.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Oh helpe hoa: Light, a Surgeon.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: ‘Tis he: O braue Iago, honeſt, and iuſt,
That haſt ſuch Noble ſenſe of thy Friends wrong,
Thou teacheſt me. Minion, your deere lyes dead,
And your vnbleſt Fate highes: Strumpet I come:
For of my heart, thoſe Charmes thine Eyes, are blotted.
Thy Bed luſt-ſtain’d, ſhall with Luſts blood bee ſpotted.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: What hoa? no Watch? No paſſage?
Murther, Murther.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: ‘Tis ſome miſchance, the voyce is very direfull.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Oh helpe.

speech.speaker: Lodo.
speech.line: Hearke.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Oh wretched Villaine.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Two or three groane. ‘Tis heauy night;
Theſe may be counterfeits: Let’s think’t vnſafe
To come into the cry, without more helpe.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Nobody come: then ſhall I bleed to death.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Hearke.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Here’s one comes in his ſhirt, with Light, and
Weapons.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Who’s there?
Who’s noyſe is this that cries on murther?

speech.speaker: Lodo.
speech.line: We do not know.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Do not you heare a cry?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Heere, heere: for heauen ſake helpe me.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: This is Othello’s Ancient, as I take it.

speech.speaker: Lodo.
speech.line: The ſame indeede, a very valiant Fellow.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: What are you heere, that cry ſo greeuouſly?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Iago? Oh I am ſpoyl’d, vndone by Villaines:
Giue me ſome helpe.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: O mee, Lieutenant!
What Villaines haue done this?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: I thinke that one of them is heereabout.
And cannot make away.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Oh treacherous Villaines:
What are you there? Come in, and giue ſome helpe.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: O helpe me there.

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: That’s one of them.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Oh murd’rous Slaue! O Villaine!

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: O damn’d Iago! O inhumane Dogge!

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Kill men i’th’ darke?
Where be theſe bloody Theeues?
How ſilent is this Towne? Hoa, murther, murther.
What may you be? Are you of good, or euill?

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: As you ſhall proue vs, praiſe vs.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Signior Lodouico?

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: He Sir.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I cry you mercy: here’s Caſſio hurt by Villaines.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Caſſio?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: How is’t Brother?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: My Legge is cut in two.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Marry heauen forbid:
Light Gentlemen, Ile binde it with my ſhirt.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: What is the matter hoa? Who is’t that cry’d?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Who is’t that cry’d?

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Oh my deere Caſſio,
My ſweet Caſſio: Oh Caſſio, Caſſio, Caſſio.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: O notable Strumpet. Caſſio, may you ſuſpeƈt
Who they ſhould be, that haue thus mangled you?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: I am ſorry to finde you thus;
I haue beene to ſeeke you.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Lend me a Garter. So: — Oh for a Chaire
To beare him eaſily hence.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Alas he faints. Oh Caſſio, Caſſio, Caſſio.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Gentlemen all, I do ſuſpeƈt this Traſh
To be a party in this Iniurie.
Patience awhile, good Caſſio. Come, come;
Lend me a Light: know we this face, or no?
Alas my Friend, and my deere Countryman
Rodorigo? No: Yes ſure: Yes, ‘tis Rodorigo.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: What, of Venice?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Euen he Sir: Did you know him?

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Know him? I.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Signior Gratiano? I cry your gentle pardon:
Theſe bloody accidents muſt excuſe my Manners,
That ſo negleƈted you.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: I am glad to ſee you.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: How do you Caſſio? Oh, a Chaire, a Chaire.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Rodorigo?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: He, he, ‘tis he:
Oh that’s well ſaid, the Chaire.
Some good man beare him carefully from hence,
Ile fetch the Generall’s Surgeon. For you Miſtris,
Saue you your labour. He that lies ſlaine heere (Caſſio)
Was my deere friend. What malice was between you?

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: None in the world: nor do I know the man?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: What? looke you pale? Oh beare him o’th’ Ayre.
Stay you good Gentlemen. Looke you pale, Miſtris?
Do you perceiue the gaſtneſſe of her eye?
Nay, if you ſtare, we ſhall heare more anon.
Behold her well: I pray you looke vpon her:
Do you ſee Gentlemen? Nay, guiltineſſe will ſpeake
Though tongues were out of vſe.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Alas, what is the matter?
What is the matter, Husband?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Caſſio hath heere bin ſet on in the darke
By Rodorigo, and Fellowes that are ſcap’d:
He’s almoſt ſlaine, and Rodorigo quite dead.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Alas good Gentleman: alas good Caſſio.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: This is the fruits of whoring. Prythe Æmilia,
Go know of Caſſio where he ſupt to night.
What, do you ſhake at that?

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: He ſupt at my houſe, but I therefore ſhake not.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: O did he ſo? I charge you go with me.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Oh fie vpon thee Strumpet.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: I am no Strumpet, but of life as honeſt,
As you that thus abuſe me.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: As I? Fie vpon thee.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Kinde Gentlemen:
Let’s go ſee poore Caſſio dreſt.
Come Miſtris, you muſt tel’s another Tale.
Æmilia, run you to the Cittadell,
And tell my Lord and Lady, what hath happ’d:
Will you go on afore? This is the night
That either makes me, or foredoes me quight.

scene.stagedir: Enter Othello, and Deſdemona in her bed.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: It is the Cauſe, it is the Cauſe (my Soule)
Let me not name it to you, you chaſte Starres,
It is the Cauſe. Yet Ile not ſhed her blood,
Nor ſcarre that whiter ſkin of hers, then Snow,
And ſmooth as Monumentall Alablaſter:
Yet ſhe muſt dye, elſe ſhee’l betray more men:
Put out the Light, and then put out the Light:
If I quench thee, thou flaming Miniſter,
I can againe thy former light reſtore,
Should I repent me. But once put out thy Light,
Thou cunning’ſt Patterne of excelling Nature,
I know not where is that Promethaean heate
That can thy Light re-Lume.
When I haue pluck’d thy Roſe,
I cannot giue it vitall growth againe,
It needs muſt wither. Ile ſmell thee on the Tree.
Oh Balmy breath, that doſt almoſt perſwade
Iuſtice to breake her Sword. One more, one more:
Be thus when thou art dead, and I will kill thee,
And loue thee after. One more, and that’s the laſt.
So ſweet, was ne’re ſo fatall. I muſt weepe,
But they are cruell Teares: This ſorrow’s heauenly,
It ſtrikes, where it doth loue. She wakes.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
