speech.line: Who’s there? Othello?

speech.speaker: Othel.
speech.line: I Deſdemona.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Will you come to bed, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Haue you pray’d to night, Deſdemon?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I my Lord.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: If you bethinke your ſelfe of any Crime
Vnreconcil’d as yet to Heauen, and Grace,
Solicite for it ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Alacke, my Lord,
What may you meane by that?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Well, do it, and be breefe, I will walke by:
I would not kill thy vnprepared Spirit,
No, Heauens fore-fend) I would not kill thy Soule.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Talke you of killing?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I, I do.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Then Heauen haue mercy on mee.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Amen, with all my heart.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: If you ſay, I hope you will not kill me.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Humh.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: And yet I feare you: for you’re fatall then
When your eyes rowle ſo.
Why I ſhould feare, I know not,
Since guiltineſſe I know not: But yet I feele I feare.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Thinke on thy ſinnes.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: They are Loues I beare to you.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I, and for that thou dy’ſt.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: That death’s vnnaturall, that kils for louing.
Alas, why gnaw you ſo your nether-lip?
Some bloody paſſion ſhakes your very Frame:
Theſe are portents: but yet I hope, I hope,
They do not point on me.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Peace, and be ſtill.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I will ſo: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: That Handkerchiefe
Which I ſo lou’d, and gaue thee, thou gau’ſt to Caſſio.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: No by my Life, and Soule: ſend for the man,
And aske him.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Sweet Soule, take heed, take heed of Periury,
Thou art on thy death-bed.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: I, but not yet to dye.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Preſently.
Therefore confeſſe thee freely of thy ſinne:
For to deny each Article with Oath,
Cannot remoue, nor choake the ſtrong Conception
That I do grone withall. Thou art to dye.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: O Heauen haue mercy on me.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I ſay, Amen.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: And haue you mercy too. I neuer did
Offend you in my life: neuer lou’d Caſſio,
But with ſuch generall warrantie of Heauen,
As I might loue. I neuer gaue him Token.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: By Heauen I ſaw my Handkerchiefe in’s hand.
O periur’d woman, thou do’ſt ſtone my heart,
And makes me call, what I intend to do,
A Murther, which I thought a Sacrifice.
I ſaw the Handkerchiefe.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: He found it then:
I neuer gaue it him: Send, for him hither:
Let him confeſſe a truth.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: He hath confeſt.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: What, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: That he hath vs’d thee.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: How? vnlawfully?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: He will not ſay ſo.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: No: his mouth is ſtopp’d:
Honest Iago hath ‘tane order for’t.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Oh, my feare interprets. What is he dead?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Had all his haires bin liues, my great Reuenge
Had ſtomacke for them all.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Alas, he is betray’d, and I vndone.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Out Strumpet: weep’ſt thou for him to my face?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: O baniſh me, my Lord, but kill me not.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Downe Strumpet.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: Kill me to morrow, let me liue to night.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Nay, if you ſtriue.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: But halfe an houre.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Being done, there is no pawſe.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: But while I ſay one prayer.

speech.speaker: Oth
speech.line: It is too late. Smothers her.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: My Lord, my Lord? What hoa?
My Lord, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: What noiſe is this? Not dead? not yet quite dead?
I that am cruell, am yet mercifull,
I would not haue thee linger in thy paine?
So, ſo.

speech.speaker: Æmil. within.
speech.line: What hoa? my Lord, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Oh good my Lord, I would ſpeake a word
with you.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Yes: ‘Tis Æmilia: by and by. Shee’s dead.
‘Tis like ſhe comes to ſpeake of Caſſio’s death:
The noiſe was high. Hah, no more moouing?
Still as the Graue. Shall ſhe come in? Wer’t good?
I thinke ſhe ſtirres againe. No, what’s beſt to do?
If ſhe come in, ſhee’l ſure ſpeake to my wife:
My wife, my wife: what wife? I haue no wife.
Oh inſupportable! Oh heauy houre!
Me thinkes, it ſhould be now a huge Eclipſe
Of Sunne, and Moone; and that th’ affrighted Globe
Did yawne at Alteration.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: I do beſeech you
That I may ſpeake with you. Oh good my Lord.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I had forgot thee: oh come in Æmilia.
Soft, by and by, let me the Curtaines draw.
Where art thou? What’s the matter with thee now?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Oh my good Lord, yonders foule Murthers
done.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: What? now?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: But now, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: It is the very error of the Moone,
She comes more neerer Earth then ſhe was wont,
And makes men mad.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Caſſio, my Lord, hath kill’d
A young Venetian, call’d Rodorigo.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Rodorigo kill’d? and Caſſio kill’d?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: No, Caſſio is not kill’d.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Not Caſſio kill’d? Then Murther’s out of tune,
And ſweet Reuenge growes harſh.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: O falſely, falſely murder’d.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Alas! what cry is that?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: That? What?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Out, and alas, that was my Ladies voice.
Helpe, helpe hoa, helpe. Oh Ladie ſpeake againe,
Sweet Deſdemona, oh ſweet Miſtris, ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: A guiltleſſe death, I dye.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Oh who hath done this deed?

speech.speaker: Deſ.
speech.line: No body: I my ſelfe, farewell:
Commend me to my kinde Lord: oh farewell.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Why, how ſhould ſhe be murdred?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Alas: who knowes?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: You heare her ſay her ſelfe, it was not I.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: She ſaid ſo: I muſt needs report the truth.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: She’s like a Liar gone to burning hell,
‘Twas I that kill’d her.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Oh the more Angell ſhe, and you the black-
er Diuell.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: She turn’d to folly: and ſhe was a whore.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Thou do’ſt bely her, and thou art a diuell.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: She was falſe as water.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Thou art raſh as fire, to ſay
That ſhe was falſe. Oh ſhe was heauenly true.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Caſſio did top her: Ask thy husband elſe.
O, I were damn’d beneath all depth in hell:
But that I did proceed vpon iuſt grounds
To this extremity. Thy Husband knew it all.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: My Husband?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Thy Husband.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: That ſhe was falſe to Wedlocke?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I, with Caſſio: had ſhe bin true,
If Heauen would make me ſuch another world,
Of one entyre and perfeƈt Chryſolite,
I’ld not haue ſold her for it.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: My Husband?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I, ‘twas he that told me on her firſt,
An honeſt man he is, and hates the ſlime
That ſtickes on filthy deeds.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: My Husband?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: What needs this itterance, Woman?
I ſay, thy Husband.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Oh Miſtris,
Villany hath made mockes with loue:
My Husband ſay ſhe was falſe?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: He, Woman;
I ſay thy Husband: Do’ſt vnderſtand the word?
My Friend, thy Husband; honeſt, honeſt Iago.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: If he ſay ſo, may his pernicious Soule
Rot halfe a graine a day: he lyes to’th’ heart,
She was too fond of her moſt filthy Bargaine.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Hah?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Do thy worſt:
This deede of thine is no more worthy Heauen,
Then thou was’t worthy her.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Peace, you were beſt.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Thou haſt not halfe that powre to do me harm,
As I haue to be hurt. Oh Gull, oh dolt,
As ignorant as durt: thou haſt done a deed
(I care not for thy Sword) Ile make thee known,
Though I loſt twenty liues. Helpe, helpe, hoa, helpe:
The Moore hath kill’d my Miſtris. Murther, murther.

speech.speaker: Mon.
speech.line: What is the matter? How now Generall?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Oh, are you come, Iago: you haue done well,
That men muſt lay their Murthers on your necke.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: What is the matter?

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: Diſproue this Villaine, if thou bee’ſt a man:
He ſayes, thou told’ſt him that his wife was falſe:
I know thou did’ſt not: thou’rt not ſuch a Villain.
Speake, for my heart is full.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I told him what I thought,
And told no more
Then what he found himſelfe was apt, and true.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: But did you euer tell him,
She was falſe?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I did.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: You told a Lye an odious damned Lye:
Vpon my Soule, a Lye; a wicked Lye.
Shee falſe with Caſſio?
Did you ſay with Caſſio?

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: With Caſſio, Miſtris?
Go too, charme your tongue.

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: I will not charme my Tongue;
I am bound to ſpeake,
My Miſtris heere lyes murthered in her bed.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Oh Heauens, forefend.

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: And your reports haue ſet the Murder on.

speech.speaker: Othello.
speech.line: Nay ſtare not Maſters,
It is true indeede.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: ‘Tis a ſtrange Truth.

speech.speaker: Mont.
speech.line: O monſtrous Aƈte.

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: Villany, villany, villany:
I thinke vpon’t, I thinke: I ſmel’t: O Villany:
I thought ſo then: Ile kill my ſelfe for greefe.
O villany! villany!

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: What, are you mad?
I charge you get you home.

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: Good Gentlemen, let me haue leaue to ſpeake:
‘Tis proper I obey him; but not now:
Perchance Iago, I will ne’re go home.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Oh, oh, oh.

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: Nay, lay thee downe, and roare:
For thou haſt kill’d the ſweeteſt innocent,
That ere did lift vp eye.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Oh ſhe was fowle!
I ſcarſe did know you Vnkle, there lies your Neece,
Whoſe breath (indeed) theſe hands haue newly ſtopp’d:
I know this aƈte ſhewes horrible and grim.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Poore Deſdemon:
I am glad thy Father’s dead,
Thy Match was mortall to him: and pure greefe
Shore his old thred in twaine. Did he liue now,
This ſight would make him do a deſperate turne:
Yea, curſe his better Angell from his ſide,
And fall to Reprobance.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: ‘Tis pittifull: but yet Iago knowes
That ſhe with Caſſio, hath the Aƈt of ſhame
A thouſand times committed. Caſſio confeſt it,
And ſhe did gratifie his amorous workes
With that Recognizance and pledge of Loue
Which I firſt gaue her: I ſaw it in his hand:
It was a Handkerchiefe, an Antique Token
My Father gaue my Mother.

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: Oh Heauen! oh heauenly Powres!

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Come, hold your peace.

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: ‘Twill out, ‘twill out. I peace?
No, I will ſpeake as liberall as the North;
Let Heauen, and Men, and Diuels, let them all,
All, all, crie ſhame againſt me, yet Ile ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Be wiſe, and get you home.

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: I will not.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Fye, your Sword vpon a Woman.

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: Oh thou dull Moore,
That Handkerchiefe thou ſpeak’ſt of
I found by Fortune, and did giue my Husband:
For often, with a ſolemne earneſtneſſe,
(More then indeed belong’d to ſuch a Trifle)
He begg’d of me, to ſteale’t.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Villanous Whore.

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: She giue it Caſſio? No, alas I found it,
And I did giu’t my Husband.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: Filth, thou lyeſt.

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: By Heauen I do not, I do not Gentlemen:
Oh murd’rous Coxcombe, what ſhould ſuch a Foole
Do with ſo good a wife?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Are there no ſtones in Heauen,
But what ſerues for the Thunder?
Precious Villaine.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: The woman falles:
Sure he hath kill’d his Wife.

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: I, I: oh lay me by my Miſtris ſide.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Hee’s gone, but his wife’s kill’d.

speech.speaker: Mon.
speech.line: ‘Tis a notorious Villain: take you this weapon
Which I haue recouer’d from the Moore:
Come guard the doore without, let him not paſſe,
But kill him rather. Ile after that ſame villaine,
For ‘tis a damned Slaue.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I am not valiant neither:
But euery Punie whipſter gets my Sword.
But why ſhould Honor out-liue Honeſty?
Let it go all.

speech.speaker: Æmil.
speech.line: What did thy Song boad Lady?
Hearke, canſt thou heare me? I will play the Swan,
And dye in Muſicke: Willough, Willough, Willough.
Moore, ſhe was chaſte: She lou’d thee, cruell Moore,
So come my Soule to bliſſe, as I ſpeake true:
So ſpeaking as I thinke, alas, I dye.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I haue another weapon in this Chamber,
It was a Sword of Spaine, the Ice brookes temper:
Oh heere it is: Vnkle I muſt come forth.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: If thou attempt it, it will coſt thee deere;
Thou haſt no weapon, and perforce muſt ſuffer.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Looke in vpon me then, and ſpeake with me,
Or naked as I am I will aſſault thee.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: What is the matter?

speech.speaker: Othel.
speech.line: Behold, I haue a weapon:
A better neuer did it ſelfe ſuſtaine
Vpon a Soldiers Thigh. I haue ſeene the day,
That with this little Arme, and this good Sword,
I haue made my way through more impediments
Then twenty times your ſtop. But (oh vaine boaſt)
Who can controll his Fate? ‘Tis not ſo now.
Be not affraid, though you do ſee me weapon’d:
Heere is my iournies end, heere is my butt
And verie Sea-marke of my vtmoſt Saile.
Do you go backe diſmaid? ‘Tis a loſt feare:
Man but a Ruſh againſt Othello’s breſt,
And he retires. Where ſhould Othello go?
Now: how doſt thou looke now? Oh ill-Starr’d wench,
Pale as thy Smocke: when we ſhall meete at compt,
This looke of thine will hurle my Soule from Heauen,
And Fiends will ſnatch at it. Cold, cold, my Girle?
Euen like thy Chaſtity. O curſed, curſed Slaue!
Whip me ye Diuels,
From the poſſeſſion of this Heauenly ſight:
Blow me about in windes, roaſt me in Sulphure,
Waſh me in ſteepe-downe gulfes of Liquid fire.
Oh Deſdemon! dead Deſdemon: dead. Oh, oh!

scene.stagedir: Enter Lodouico, Caſſio, Montano, and Iago, with Officers.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Where is this raſh, and moſt vnfortunate man?

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: That’s he that was Othello: heere I am.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Where is that Viper?
Bring the Villaine forth.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I look down towards his feet; but that’s a Fable,
If that thou bee’ſt a Diuell, I cannot kill thee.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Wrench his Sword from him.

speech.speaker: Iago.
speech.line: I bleed Sir, but not kill’d.

speech.speaker: Othel.
speech.line: I am not ſorry neither, Il’d haue thee liue:
For in my ſenſe, ‘tis happineſſe to die.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Oh thou Othello, that was once ſo good,
Falne in the praƈtiſe of a curſed Slaue,
What ſhall be ſaide to thee.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Why any thing:
An honourable Murderer, if you will:
For nought I did in hate, but all in Honour.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: This wretch hath part confeſt his Villany:
Did you and he conſent in Caſſio’s death.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Deere Generall, I neuer gaue you cauſe.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I do beleeue it, and I aske your pardon:
Will you, I pray, demand that demy-Diuell,
Why he hath thus enſnar’d my Soule and Body.

speech.speaker: Iag.
speech.line: Demand me nothing: what you know, you know:
From this time forth, I neuer will ſpeake word.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: What? not to pray?

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Torments will ope your lips.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Well, thou doſt beſt.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Sir,
You ſhall vnderſtand what hath befalne,
(Which, as I thinke, you know not) heere is a Letter
Found in the pocket of the ſlaine Rodorigo,
And heere another, the one of them imports
The death of Caſſio, to be vndertooke
By Rodorigo.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: O Villaine!

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: Moſt Heatheniſh, and moſt groſſe.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Now, heere’s another diſcontented paper
Found in his pocket too: and this it ſeemes
Rodorigo meant t’haue ſent this damned villaine:
But that (belike) Iago in the interim
Came in, and ſatisfi’d him.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Oh thou pernitious Caitiffe;
How came you (Caſſio) by that Handkerchiefe
That was my wiues?

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: I found it in my Chamber:
And he himſelfe confeſt it but euen now,
That there he dropt it for a ſpeciall purpoſe,
Which wrought to his deſire.

speech.speaker: Othel.
speech.line: O Foole, foole, foole!

speech.speaker: Caſſio.
speech.line: There is beſides, in Rodorigo’s Letter,
How he vpbraides Iago, that he made him
Braue me vpon the Watch: whereon it came
That I was caſt: and euen but now he ſpake
(After long ſeeming dead) Iago hurt him,
Iago ſet him on.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: You muſt forſake this roome, and go with vs:
Your Power, and your Command is taken off,
And Caſſio rules in Cyprus. For this Slaue,
If there be any cunning Crueltie,
That can torment him much, and hold him long,
It ſhall be his. You ſhall cloſe Priſoner reſt,
Till that the Nature of your fault be knowne
To the Venetian State. Come, bring away.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: Soft you; a word or two before you goe:
I haue done the State ſome ſeruice, and they know’t:
No more of that. I pray you in your Letters,
When you ſhall theſe vnluckie deeds relate,
Speake of me, as I am. Nothing extenuate,
Nor ſet downe ought in malice.
Then muſt you ſpeake,
Of one that lou’d not wiſely, but too well:
Of one, not eaſily Iealious, but being wrought,
Perplexed in the extreame: Of one, whoſe hand
(Like the baſe Iudean) threw a Pearle away
Richer then all his Tribe: Of one, whoſe ſubdu’d Eyes,
Albeit vn-vſed to the melting moode,
Drops teares as faſt as the Arabian Trees
Their Medicinable gumme. Set you downe this:
And ſay beſides, that in Aleppo once,
Where a malignant, and a Turbond-Turke
Beate a Venetian, and traduc’d the State,
I tooke by th’ throat the circumciſed Dogge,
And ſmoate him, thus.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Oh bloody period.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: All that is ſpoke, is marr’d.

speech.speaker: Oth.
speech.line: I kiſt thee, ere I kill’d thee: No way but this,
Killing my ſelfe, to dye vpon a kiſſe. Dyeſ

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: This did I feare, but thought he had no weapon:
For he was great of heart.

speech.speaker: Lod.
speech.line: Oh Sparton Dogge:
More fell then Anguiſh, Hunger, or the Sea:
Looke on the Tragicke Loading of this bed:
This is thy worke:
The Obieƈt poyſons Sight,
Let it be hid. Gratiano, keepe the houſe,
And ſeize vpon the Fortunes of the Moore,
For they ſucceede on you. To you, Lord Gouernor,
Remaines the Cenſure of this helliſh villaine:
The Time, the Place, the Torture, oh inforce it:
My ſelfe will ſtraight aboord, and to the State,
This heauie Aƈt, with heauie heart relate.

personae.persona: Lodouico, and Gratiano, two Noble Venetians.
